comment_text.mn59:1.3: Pañcakaṅga features as a prominent devotee of the Buddha in MN 78, MN 127, and in a parallel to the current sutta at SN 36.19. As thapati (“chamberlain”) he was the ranking official under Pasenadi. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.17–18 tells us that royal authority goes from the king, to the king’s brother, to the thapati, to the village head. Similarly, Atharva Veda 2.32.4a and 5.23.11a mention the thapati directly after the king. SN 55.6:15.1 shows the thapati was trusted with the most intimate and sensitive duties of the court. Elsewhere we learn that they shared the meal and carriage with the king, accompanying him on military campaigns (MN 89:18.1), while SN 55.6:1.4 shows them engaged in governing the provinces. Thus the thapati was the highest non-royal official in the court, entrusted with governing, advising, and security of the household. | There are several individuals called Udāyī, and it is not possible to distinguish them all.
comment_text.mn59:5.1: The Buddha’s reply here develops the theme of “non-categorical” statements introduced in the previous sutta, showing that the same reality can be spoken of in many different ways.
comment_text.mn59:7.3: In discussing the path, the Buddha focuses on pleasure.
comment_text.mn59:10.4: This validates Pañcakaṅga’s view that neutral feeling can be reckoned as a subtle kind of pleasure.
comment_text.mn59:15.6: Since all feeling is conditioned, and what is conditioned is suffering, the cessation of feeling is reckoned as pleasurable.

root_text.mn59:5.1: “santaññeva kho, ānanda, pariyāyaṁ pañcakaṅgo thapati udāyissa nābbhanumodi, santaññeva ca pana pariyāyaṁ udāyī pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa nābbhanumodi.
root_text.mn59:5.2: Dvepānanda, vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena, tissopi vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena, pañcapi vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena, chapi vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena, aṭṭhārasapi vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena, chattiṁsapi vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena, aṭṭhasatampi vedanā vuttā mayā pariyāyena.
root_text.mn59:5.3: Evaṁ pariyāyadesito kho, ānanda, mayā dhammo.
root_text.mn59:5.4: Evaṁ pariyāyadesite kho, ānanda, mayā dhamme ye aññamaññassa subhāsitaṁ sulapitaṁ na samanujānissanti na samanumaññissanti na samanumodissanti tesametaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ—bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharissanti.

root_text.mn59:6.9: Yaṁ kho, ānanda, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ idaṁ vuccati kāmasukhaṁ.

root_text.mn59:7.3: Atthānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṁ sukhaṁ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
root_text.mn59:7.4: Katamañcānanda, etamhā sukhā aññaṁ sukhaṁ abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca?

root_text.mn59:16.1: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, ānanda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.mn59:16.2: ‘saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ samaṇo gotamo āha; tañca sukhasmiṁ paññapeti.
root_text.mn59:16.4: Evaṁvādino, ānanda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
root_text.mn59:16.5: ‘na kho, āvuso, bhagavā sukhaṁyeva vedanaṁ sandhāya sukhasmiṁ paññapeti;

root_text.mn59:16.8: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn59:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn59:1.3: Then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga went up to Venerable Udāyī, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn59:1.4: “Sir, how many feelings has the Buddha spoken of?”
translation_text.mn59:1.5: “Chamberlain, the Buddha has spoken of three feelings:
translation_text.mn59:1.7: The Buddha has spoken of these three feelings.”
translation_text.mn59:1.8: When he said this, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,
translation_text.mn59:1.9: “Sir, Udāyī, the Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings.
translation_text.mn59:1.12: The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”
translation_text.mn59:2.1: For a second time, Udāyī said to Pañcakaṅga,
translation_text.mn59:2.2: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings,
translation_text.mn59:2.6: For a second time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,
translation_text.mn59:2.7: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,
translation_text.mn59:3.1: And for a third time, Udāyī said to Pañcakaṅga,
translation_text.mn59:3.2: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings,
translation_text.mn59:3.6: And for a third time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,
translation_text.mn59:3.7: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,
translation_text.mn59:3.11: But neither was able to persuade the other.
translation_text.mn59:4.1: Venerable Ānanda heard this discussion between Udāyī and Pañcakaṅga.
translation_text.mn59:4.2: Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn59:4.3: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
translation_text.mn59:4.4: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn59:5.1: “Ānanda, the explanation by the mendicant Udāyī, which the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga didn’t agree with, was quite correct. But the explanation by Pañcakaṅga, which Udāyī didn’t agree with, was also quite correct.
translation_text.mn59:5.2: In one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
translation_text.mn59:5.3: I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways.
translation_text.mn59:5.4: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will fight, quarrel, and dispute, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
translation_text.mn59:5.5: I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways.
translation_text.mn59:5.6: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
translation_text.mn59:6.1: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn59:6.3: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn59:6.7: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn59:6.8: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn59:6.9: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure.
translation_text.mn59:7.1: There are those who might say that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience. But I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn59:7.3: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:7.5: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn59:7.6: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:8.1: There are those who would say that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience. But I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn59:8.3: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:8.5: It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. …
translation_text.mn59:9.2: There is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:9.4: It’s when, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’ …
translation_text.mn59:10.2: There is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:10.4: It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. …
translation_text.mn59:11.2: There is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:11.4: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. …
translation_text.mn59:12.2: There is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:12.4: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …
translation_text.mn59:13.2: There is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:13.4: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. …
translation_text.mn59:14.2: There is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:14.4: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.mn59:14.5: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:15.1: There are those who would say that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience. But I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn59:15.3: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:15.5: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.mn59:15.6: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
translation_text.mn59:16.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.mn59:16.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness.
translation_text.mn59:16.4: When wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them,
translation_text.mn59:16.5: ‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling.
translation_text.mn59:16.6: The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it is found, and in whatever context.’”
translation_text.mn59:16.7: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn59:16.8: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
